div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE

The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definitely engaged as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles, Gibraltar, Plymouth and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisl Express Steamer leaves Port Said directly the Indian Malls arrive Passengers can go on board the evening before.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternnon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving in London at the very convienent hour of 4.56 p.m. on Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fare is 22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisl or vial Marseilles
Passengers having paid full fare in one direction are allowed an avatement of 25 percent on returning within 12 months.
In addition to the above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 to 7,000 tons steemers to London, calling at Malta or Marseilles.
TO THE EAST.

The Mail Steamers leave Suez for Adenspo Bombay every Wednesday, and for Australia and China every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcutta, fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passengers can embark at Port Said.
Messrs Thos. Cook and Son (Egypt) Ltd. - Cairo.
Grosen Royle Reg - Port Said.
Mussers Hasulden and Co. - Alexandria.
F G Davidson Superintendent P and O. S. N. Company in Egypt - Suez.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: Unsettled weather conditions have prevailed since Saturday, heave showers of rain alternating with short spells of sunshine. There was a slight gale on Saturday and again on Sunday morning, but in the afternoon the wind dropped, only to rise again at 10 p.m., the force of the anemometer reaching 55. Today the weather appears a little more settled but cloudy, with a fresh breeze from the S. Barometer falling.

div.head: THE CAPITULATIONS.
div.p: We have never regarded the Capitulations as asorosanot, and recent events have confirmed us in our view that these institutions hav had their day in Egypt. Their existence hase for some time been superfluous, it is now becoming a source of anxiety to all European residents who wish to see harmonious relations existing between Europeans and the natives of the country, and has long since irritated all patriotic Egyptians, who cannot but feel considerable vexation at the difference in the treatment accorded to the native subject who maltreats a European and the toreign subject who mishandles a native. We have no desire to accuse any nationality, any consulate, of partiality in its treatment of the cases that arise between natives and Europeans. We recognize that the European officials and magistrates who at present preside over and compose Consular Courts are an honorable body of men who aim at justice and do their best to be impervious to external influences. But nothing is gained by blinking out eyes to the fact that these courts have not always given satisfaction, and that instances could be given where their decisions have been grossly unfair and have been explained at times by the incapacity, at times by the vensility, of judges. What has occurred before may occur again: every service contains men who are inferior in mental calibre to the bulk of their colleagues, and it is notorious that even judges of the Consular Courts have before now incurred suspicion of dishonesty and worse.

Let us then put ourselves for a moment in the place of an educated native of Egypt and consider the Capitulations from his point of view. Would not our thoughts run much as follows: "I, Mohamed Effendi Selim, have no quarrel with the men who compose the courts, but I do not see the necessity for these difference in the treatment of European and native criminals. My servant's brother, a silly fellow no doubt, broke the head of a subject of the King of Lithuania the other day, and by out law he went to gaol, and very rightly too. But when a subject of the Prince of Baratavia stabbed the boawab of the house three doors up the street, who tried to stop him knifing a man in a low café, and the bowab died of his wounds, certain Baratarians on the jury lent a ready ear to the stories of witnesses whose proper place was the dock, and the end of it all was that the foreigner was let off with a ridiculously light sentence. Had he been a native subject he would have had twenty years. Other foreigners have been let out on bail when charged with serious crimes against us and have not been prevented from fleeing the country and evading justice. Our men, if they break heads or use knives, go to prison at once. Their trial nowadays comes quickly, but the subjects of foreign countries wait-free-for months, during which they may bribe witnesses or leave the country. Even if the await trial and the proper forms are observed we notice the difference in the treatment, and if educated men feel as I do, what is said among the ignorant who do not understand legal procedure? Why this, that there is one law for the Moslems and one for the foreigners, that the judges must of a surely be bribed, and that this is tyranny and injustice. We cannot depend on the Consular Courts, they must be honest and just one year but they may disappoint up the next, and the difference in procedure and in penalties puzzles our lower class. There are matters for which our laws inflict severer punishments that theirs, and they do not understand it."

Given such a state of mind, can we wonder that any outbreak of crime on the part of low-class Europeans against natives leads to disturbances, for this is not the first time that the Rue Hamamil and Anastasi-street have seen affrays. Instead of looking for evidence of fast conspiracies and portentous plots, let us face the fact that Alexandria contains a multitude of European and native blackguards and that is the position of the town, the first seaport of the Levant, makes it impossible to prevent constant additions to their numbers. "Uno non deficit alter"-you deport a dozen undesirables and thirteen arrive by the next boat. Therefore we must hope for the establishment of Courts in which natives and Europeans will be properly represented on the Bench and in which, whatever the nationality of the European tried on a charge of committing a crime against a native, he will be tried under the same Code and with the same procedure. Otherwise we must expect dissatisfaction among the natives, and as a large proportion of them are ignorant men they may be counted upon to manifest their dissatisfaction by stupid violence. Very regrettable that they should be stupid and violent, but, my dear objector, argument has not yet superseded the half-brick at home, and you show a certain vaivete in deploring the fact in Egypt the argument of the nabout still survives.

div.head: YESTERDAY IN ALEXANDRIA. NO RENEWAL OF DISTURBANCE TRIAL OF RIOTERS COMMENCES.
div.p: A great deal was witten and said last week as to what might be expected to occur in the city yesterday. How far there was any real ground for alarm must remain a matter of uncertaintv The certainty is that nothing whatever of an untoward character happened. The trial of the natives accused of participation in the late riot proceeded without anything more serioas than a good deal of shooting in the arrest as the vans conveying the prisoners arrived and departed, and nothing worthy of note took place in Rosetta street

The authorities are to be commended for the very effective precautions taken against a further riotous outbreak. Mounted polioe pa- trolled the low quarters of the town, and the latest attempt at riot wonld have been suppressed before it could have attained any serions proportions. But so quiet was every neighbor- hood, that a stranger unaware of the history of he last few days would have wondered what the extra display of force meant. We trust that this state of things may continue and that the rowdyism that has been, unfortunately, so rife among the lower classes, both European and native, may have received a check that will prove effective in the future.

The trial of the persons implicated in the disturbances of Sunday week took plaoe yes- terday morning, in the Native Court. Rosetta- street The court was prodded over by Abl El Megid Bey Fend, and Mahfonz Bey represented the Parquet, Hopkinson Bey, Morice Bey, and Haddaya Bey being present The number of the accused, brought into he court was 104. In the court-yard a crowd of about 200 natives had gathered, and 40 policemen were on duty.

At half-past eleven the president of the Parquet began his speech for the prosecution, naming the persons suspected of rioting. After giving particulars of the charge against 60 or 7O prisoners, Mahtouz Bey asked the Court to allow 5 minuter respite, and this was granted. On resuming, Mahfeuz Bey contnued reading the long list of accused, making comments as he went on. When the reading of the list had been concluded, the president of ihe Patquet addressed the judge somewhat as follows;—

"I trust you are not surprised at the spectacle of 104 persons under trial, as the mob that took part in the disturbance of Sun- day afternoon, of which these persons formed part, numbered 15,000 individuals. Indeed, we had not a sufficient number of police to arrest every one who took part in the distur- bance, and that is why the Fire Brigade was re- quisitioned to disperse the thousands of people. Therefore we cannot particularise the circum- stances of the event so far as to report what each of the rioters did. It was some what impossible to do so in such a wide-spread disturbanoe. We arrested 400 and after inquiry have discharged 1 half that number. The other haif, i e., the 200 prisoners, were seen by the police and the sheikhs of the quarters to be making a disturbauoe. Had there been witnesses to prove that the other 200 or part of them had taken part in the troubles we should of course have kept them to be tried. Had this disturbance taken plaoe 15 years ago the Court would probably not have found an article in the Penal Code applicable to the present case, for it is only 15 years since Articles 220 and 221 were added to the code, owing to a similar incedent which took place at that time... In short, we have brought these people before you in the hope that they will receive severe punishment to prevent furhter public disturbances. The case was first in the hands of the police, and it then passed into those of the Parquet, and now, the enquiry being oompiete I, beg to lay the case in your hands,trusting you will bear the respon- sibility of giving the proper judgment."

At the conclusion of the speech for the pro- secution, some discussion took plaoe as to the defence of the prisoners, and finally the hearing was adjourned till next Saturday. The trial of the second batch of 71 prisoners took place this morning in the same Court, and was still proceeding as we went to press.

div.head: SUEZ CANAL COLLISION.
JUDGMENT IN CHATHAM CASE.
CLAN CUMMING HELD RESPONSIBLE.
div.p: Sir Gorell Barnes and Trinity Masters, in die Admiralty Conrt, on Satnrday we k, joncloded the hearing of the oase of the owners if the Chatham and her crew, suing for loss of fffeotH, v. the owners i f the Clan Camming ind freight. Tbi« was a claim and oonnter- ilaim for damages, owing to a oollision which xoarred between the two vessels in the Suez Banal on September 5 last, resulting in the linking of the Chatham, which oanght fire. 3he wau laden wittyi cargo of 180,' OOlbs. of iyuamite, and 160,600 detonators. The sink- ing of the Chatham leenlted in blocking the Muial traffic for a few days, until, by order of tbeqanal authorities, the vessel was blown np. The aotiou now came before the court for a ieoision as to which of the two vessels was to blame for the oollision.

Iu giving judgment his Lordship said that in irder to appreciate the oollision it was ne- sestary to tee how these vessels were aproaoh- ing eaoh othur. Ac the part of the canal where the oollisii-n oconned, vessels proosediug louihwaid had to ' tie np" to posts whenever it was neoessaiy for steamers to past np. His Lordship then deait with the rales applying to lse of the searoh-iight and other lighta which iad beeu laid down, m the canal regulations, i'he southern-going vessel must show the iniliant light till ftie pat into the siding, and iben give tbe ordinary light to show she had ;ot iheie. A vessel under enoh oiroumsianoea nuat aot reasonably wheu going south, while !id one going north must watoh and see she lid not get too near the other ship. He thought hat, having regard to the impossiuiiity ot >eiug certain ot the distanoe separating two rcss- Is under these oiroomstanoes, it wa» ibsolutely necessary for the vessel going north- vt>r l to keep herself well in hand, so that she vas oowpletely prepared to deal with any iveutuaheiei she jmght meet from the rhip ouuing south. Sir Gorell Barnes pcin ei out hat each side argued that the other res el had acted in an unreasonable mau- ler, and it was therefore neoe>sary to see vbat really did happen. He had no donbt hat the Chatham was at the time of the oolli- ion practically a stationary ship, and had toted in precisely tin same manner as the had io ed on two previous occasions, wheu she had Irawn up to allow three other vessels to psms. Phe rest of the oa»e was somewhat simple, ieoan«e the collision was a severe ooe, the Han Camming offttug, as she did, right into he bows of the Chatham as iar as the windlass. Phe oely other question was to examine rbe her the Clan Cumining bed proceeded nth proper and reasonable precaution. In his ipmion, and that of the Elder Brethren, those n oharge of the defendanta' ship did not aot essonably in approach ng the Cuatham, having igued to the ludiQations given to them. The blame for the collision rested solely on the bad lavigation of the Clan Camming, and she must ie louud alone to blame for the oollision.
After some little argument the question as o whether the ship was properly blown up was aft for farther oousideration.

div.head: ITALIAN MISSION FROM ALEXANDRIA
div.p: It is not improbable that the Italian Government will despatch an important expidition from Alexandria to Tripoli. Although it is officially denied that the Turkish Government has refused permission for an Italian scientific mission to land at Tripoli, it is nevertheless true that the Italian Ambassador at Constantinople was recently sounded bu the Porte authorities as to whether, in the event of permission being refused, the mission was likely to land at Alexandria, and from thence penetrate into the hinterland of Tripoli.

The mission, which will be under the leadership of the well-known explorer Ferraudi, will not be entirely scientific, but will also aim at preparing the way for a peaceful penetration of Tripoli by Italy.

div.p: Ou behalf of the Bodlean Library, Mr. Offutd has seonied a somewhat large ooileotion of fragmentary Haorew and Aramaio mano- senpto which it u to be hoped, when oarefnlly examined by the Oxford paleographers, will prove not oniy important, but perhaps oom- piete some of ihe portions of oodioeo already at Ox ord or Camonuge. So few papyri, or manuscripts, now reaoh Cairo because agents of European museums travel into the Egyptian provuioes to obtain them from the frUaheen, that it is fortunate that this series of duon menta has been found oomparatively intact.

div.head:
RUSSIAN REVOLUTION
TROOPS INSUBORDINATE
FIERCE FIGHTING
SITUATION IN MOSCOW SERIOUS

div.p: The first batches of troops from Manchuri that have arrived at Moscow are utterly insubordinate. They refused to obey orders route and compelled the trains to stop at different towns while they went out on orgies
The printers of the reactionary newspaper "Revert" have struck because they have not been allowed to intersperse articles with their own comments.
A revolution has broken oat at Batum, Poti, and Kutais. The streets are barricaded and fierce fighting is taking place, the troops using artillery against the mob.
The whole council of workmen's delegates, numbering 250, have been arrested and convey ed to prison.
Dictatorial powers have been conferred on governors of provinces, proving the intention of the government to pat down the revolution with an iron hand.

The situation at Moscow is serious. The Rostoff Grenadier regiment mutinied and appointed a committee of 20 to take over the command. They mounted guns at the windows of the barracks. The authorities have not ventured upon taking any measures for the repression of the mutiny.
The revolutionists are masters of Kurland. The towns of Mittau and Riga are on fire.
The Government has chartered three steam-ers to fetch Germans from Riga, Reval, and Libau if necessary.
The international fleet has been recalled.
The Chamber has rejected the commercial modus vivendi with Spain In consequence of this vote the Cabinet has resigned.
King George has returned. His Majesty will receive M. Ralli tomorrow regarding the ministerial orisis.
In presence of the coalition of the Opposition M. Ralli has resigned.

div.head:
LORD CURZON.
ASKED TO STAND FOR THE CITY.

div.p: A strong movement in favor of inviting Lord Curzon to stand for the City is being manifested. An invitation to this fleet, based rather upon National than on party grounds has already been signed by several of the most influential bankers and merchants.
The "Times" thinks that Lord Curzon can hardly refuse the City's flattering offer if it be definitely made, although, failing that the House of Lords would be a more appropriate place for him.
Sir Alfred Thomas the Welsh leader, is enabled to state that the Government will carry out the disestablishment and disendow nent of he Anglican Church in Wales.
The Welsh Members of Parliament have repeatedly intimated they would not other wise support the Government.
The new Chinese Minister has arrived.
Mr Henry Labouchere has retired from Northampton on account of age.

div.head:
MOROCCO QUESTION.
SPEECH BY M. ROUVIER.
FRANCE'S RIGHTS.
SPEECH CAUSES MARKED IMPRESSION

div.p: Speaking in the Chamber. M. Rouvier said that the Government meant to keep the Morocco question, within proper proportions. He emphasised the foot that France would at the conference uphold her special rights and interests in Morocco. The independence of Morocco and he introduction of reforms were essential, and ''our rights were the result of negotiations, and if not all recognised , they were at all events all preserved. We calmly await the conference."

M. Rouvier stated in the Chamber that France wished to maintain in Morocco the rights which had been recognised as hers, but she respects the interests of other Powers. The Chamber closured the discussion by 401 votes against 51. This vote is considered as an approbation. The session is closed.

M. Rouvier's speech, which was a firm affirmation of the rights of France as a contiguous and Mussulman Power, produced a marked impression, and was listened to in deep silence, being heartily cheered at the finish.
The conference concerning Morocco will meet here.
The Senate has approved the vote of 11,000,000 dollars for the Panama Canal
Football. Wales beat the New Zealanders by 3 to 0. This is the first defeat of the latter during their tour.

div.head: THE AGE OF PREMIERS.
div.p: Sir Henry Campbell-Bannerman becomes Prime Minister at an age exceeded only by one Premier of modern times-Lord Palmerston— who was 71 when he attained the leading place in the Government Disraeli comes next. H was 64 when he became Prime Minister for the first rime. Gladstone was 59. Lord Salisbury 55, Mr. Balfour 54, and Lord Rosebery 46.

div.head: ON FOURPENCE A DAY.
div.p: The question whether it is possible to live on fourpence a day. or not, is to be tested io a practical way. Dr. J osiah Oldfield states in the "Chroniole" that half a dozen out of-work clerks are to be selected and given a combination of physical labour and clerical work ; and the cost of the food that is to sustain them during the exertion is not to exceed fourpence per day per head.

div.head: ANTI-MOSQUITO CAMPAIGN.
THE PREVENTION OF MALARIA.
div.p: In reference to our leading article on the subject on Saturday last, the following ex tract from the article on "The Prevention of Malaria," by Lieut. Col. Giles, in "Climate and Health," will be of interest;-

"In by far the majority of cases we must be content with a partial success all along the line, by adopting such measures as may be locally most practicable. In the case. for example, of habitations placed in the midst of canal irrigation, where ample and efficient subsoil drainage is impossible or too expensive, the attempt to destroy mosquitoes can be little bitter than a waste of time and money, for under such conditions the breeding places are so numerous, and appear so constantly in new and unexpected situations, as to defeat the utmost vigilance, and the thorough protection of all habitations against the invasion of mosquitoes, and the careful treatment of all cases with quinine, is all that can be done. On the other hand, in an exceptional case, such us that of the town of Ismailia in Egypt, where the rainfall is practically nil, and the breeding places all of artificial origin, the practical extermination of mosquitoes may be so easy matter as to be effected at a small expense in a single year, with te immediate result of reducing the cases of malaria to a tithe of their previous numbers."

All the world, however, knew or ought to know that Ismailia is the place par Excellence where success attended well-organised effort Under the superintendence of Dr. Presa, of the Canal Company, acting on the advice of Major Ross, what was at one time a hotbed of malaria has now become famous as the town which first conclusively demonstrated the possibility of preventing malaria by clearing out its flag bearer, the mosquito. What has been done in Ismailia bas been done in other places. Let us hope that in our other coastal towns at least and in Cairo the example Ismailia will not be ignored.

div.head: SINAI.
div.p: Some important remarks on the condition of Sinaitic antiquities are contained in M. Maspero's review of Capt Raymond Well's "Renoeil des Inscription* EgyptiennesdeSinai" in the "Rem Critique" of a few weeks back. In this the head of the Service des Antiquites shows clearly enough the state to which the Sinaitio inscriptions have been reduced by weather and the depredations of the Bedouin, and that the transport to the Cairo Museum of such of them as could still be saved bad al ready been began by the Service before the expedition of last winter. He farther explains how carefully the Sinaitio peninsula was sur veyed when its Egyptian monuments were in a far better state than they are now—first by Palmer and Wihon, then by M. Benendite, and more recently by Dr. Borchardt.

div.head: THE VALVE OF A NAME
div.p: Mr. Sidney Low tells in "The Standard'' a story about a Madras tradesman who brought an action against another to restrain him from using his trade name, which was English and high-sounding. The Judge of the High Court, whom we may call Sir William Ramsbury, in giving judgment against the defendant it, ex plained that he was quite at liberty to adopt any name but that preoccupied by the plaintiff "May I use any name I like ?" said the defeated litigant "Certainly," sail Mr Justice Ram b ity. The next morning his honor received a card announcing that 'Ram bury and Company" were prepared to supply him for cash on the most reasonable terms.

div.head: OUR FUTURE KING.
div.p: Some interesting stories of Prince Edward, the eldest son of the Prince of Wales, are told in the "Treasury Magazine" Christmas number. The young Prince. says the writer, on one occasion Was asked by a little girl whom he met out at tea where he lived. "We live near Whit ley' ," added the child proudly. "Ah." replied Prince Edward, with interest, "that's curious. We live near Gorribee's." Once a gentleman was telling a long and dull anecdote to the Prince and h;s brother. After a time Prince Albert began to show unmistakable signs of weariness and impatience, at which Prince Edward anxiously nudged him, whispering as he did so, "Smile, smile."

div.head: FATE OF 6,000 BIRDS.
div.p: Nearly 60,00 birds were, after two nights of fog, found dead under the lantern of Cape Grisnez lighthouse. They had been attracted by the brilliant light, and killed by flying against the lighthouse.

row.cell: Avoid at night drinking water that has not been covered for three days.
The breath is condensed in vapour Serpents become blind.
The Sun in Capricornus. Beginning of winter. The interior of the earth is warmed. Fleas appear.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: Major J. L Armitage, 1st Battalion Royal killing Belfast, has gone on retired pay under the age rules. He was a clever and popular regimental officer and hid retirement is mn h regretted. He served with both the 1st and 2nd Battalion* in the South African War, for which he holds the medals, with clasps. As already announced in these notes, he is succeeded in the appointment of second command of the 1st Battalion by Major H O. D. Hiokman from the 2nd Batta-liotn at Cairo. Major Hickman has worn the tamber of the old 19 h Yorkshire Regiment. »s He was appointed to the regiment in 1880, was transferred to he Iuniskilhngs in 1881, obtaining his company in 1889, and his majority in 1900. He served with the Yorkshires in the the Expedition of 884~85 (medal with elasp, and Khedive's star) was attached to th Egyptian army for some time, when he saw further service in the operations in the Suda , 1888, including the action of G maizah (4 h class Medjidieh, clasp) and he was with the 1st Battalion after on its memorable passage o the way to Ladysmith, including the actions of Belfast and Lydenbnrg (medal with two clasps). Major Hickman is on leave till the 31st inst, when he will assume the duties of second in command of the 1st Battalion.

Major J G. Fair, D.S.O., 21st (Empress of India's) Lanoers, Hounslow, has taken his retired pay after over twenty years' service in that smart regiment He got his first com-mission in the 21st— then a Hassar regiment —in August, 1885, his troop in 1892, and majority in March, 1900, whilst on active service. major Fair was staff officer to Gatao e at the battle of Atbara, in Kitchener's advance towards Khartoum, and at the battle of Khar-toom he was present in the same capacity (mentioned in despatches, 4th class Medjidieh, British medal, and Khedive's medal with two clasps) He also served in the South African War, earning the D.S.O. and the medal with clasps.
Recent changes in the King's Royal Rifle Corps have brought in Captains D. Blundell H llin hed-Blundell, M.V.O., and R. Sims, D.S.0, on the establishment, to which they were supernumeraries.

Lieutenant B. G. Bromhead and Sargeant H. Harvey, 1st Battalion Royal Berkshire Regiment, Dublin, passed at the in. the advanced course, including the Maxim gun, at the School of Musketry, Hythe. A note to the official announcement states that 'the knowledge displayed by Lieutenant Baggalay (11th Hassars) and Lieute-nant Bromhead was of the highest order." This was in reference to the Maxim gun.

The summary of recruiting, just issued by the War Office for 1905, shows that the results were fairly satisfactory. From 1st January of this year till the 1st October the figures were —cavalry, 2 726 ; artillery 5 745 ; engineers, 703; infantry , 19, 62; departmental corps, 1,386 : total. 29 929. Between the 1st October 1905, and the 30th u t 24.557 men enlisted— 21,498 for nine years. 1,073 for twelve years, and the remainder were short-service men. At the present rate enlistment a substantial addition to these figures is anticipated at the end of the year. The new short-service system is doing pretty well in several districts. "Homesters" the recruits are styled in bar racks.

The new Premier, Sir Henry Campbell Bannerman, is not a persona grata with the British Army. As a War Secretary in the Galvestonian Administration of 892 he was a Head failure without a single redeeming point and ultimately he blew his party and himself out of office on the cordite question. S cle-verly did he manage things that the stores of that article were almost exhausted, and an adverse vote finished him. But it was reserved for him to be the most vehement traducer of our army during the South African War, when he denounced the army for he "me h ds of barbarism" it pursued in a manner which most have been balm to the feelings of our German cousins. Whilst be and his pro-Boer followers kept the B ers in the field by their delusive speeches, he received many a hearty curse from the brave fellows who were so gallantly keeping the flag flying under the Southern Cross.
The Leviathan has been re commissioned at Chatham, with a crew of 891 officers and men, for service on the Mediterranean Station, as flagship of the Third Cruiser Squadron.

div.head: ARCHITECTURE AND ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: HOW TO BEAUTIFY THE CITY.
BY R. WILLIAMS, F.R.I.B.A.

Eves accustomed to architectural forms and details may see, here and there, in odd nooks and corners of Alexandria, many fragments of an older city. Pieces of carved or moulded stone, marble or granite may be found, here as a doorstep, there as a boundary mark, or lying prone on the ground balf-bnried in the duse Occasionally, in digging foundations, the "faes" of the digger strikes a piece of Greek sculpture or a Roman base, or a Byzantine capital, and. now and then, a piece of a great monolithic shaft is laid bare and anon come to view old culverts, drains, cisterns, and even cavernous catacombs. Much marble has disappeared for ever in the kilns of the lime burners and a few fragments, specimens of the architectural art as practised in ancient Alexandria, are saved in museums.
Alexandria's Architectural Glories.

But fragmentary as all these specimens are, sufficient of them remain to help us to piece together in our imagination some of the archi-tectural glories of the columnar halls, palaces, temples, and libraries of the great city of learning founded by Alexander some twenty-two centuries ago. But all has disappeared under the dust of ages, and.save the fragments which tell us of artistic labour and of the dauntless courage in overcoming the difficulties of hewing, carving, polishing, and transporting heavy monoliths a distance of 500 miles from Assouan to the sea, nothing remains. The ancient grandeur of the city has vanished, its great buildings , enriched with the work of the artists of its day in hand, enduring material, have fallen a prey, less to the wear and tear of time, than to the changes and chances of devastating wars.
The Old and the New.

Like Heliopolis, marked by its much older and finer monument of antiquity—a single obelisk—-so is ancient Alexandra marked by its column set up by a Human proconsul some sixteen hundred years ago. just in time to give it warrant of antiquity, but very late as times are measured in Egypt. The work of the proconsul Pompeins towers up in its lone grandeur and strength of foundation, and if the eyes of the rather roughly cut acanthus leaves of its capital could have seen. they would have become dim with sorrow as they witnessed how. one by one, vandal powers filled the columns of the many-pillared halls, loggias, and arcades that stood around and how, in lieu thereof, town upon the dust and debris of town arose, and how mounds of "shakf" were formed by the broken pottery thrown away by succeeding ages of the populations as they passed down the stream of time, and how by degrees the Alex andria of to day has arisen—a city of Mex stone, soft brick and plaster—a renaissance truly, but a mere spectre of the old, ever crumbling and taming into decay. The old robustness, the bold, spirited handling of blocks of granite and marble and the drawing thereout, with chisel point and mallet, the beauteous forms which lay hidden therein, have given place to tame ornament in fleeting plaster.
Signs of Change.

There are, however signs of change, to use words often on the lips of the great artist and man of letters William Morris, and strong hopes, yet tremulous fears, for art in this prosperous city of Alexandria. The land of Alexandria is as the land of Ophir, the gold of which was said to be good. The price of land is becoming fabulous, certain tracts of it, already high in price, have, in the space of three months, quadrupled, even though they have lain idle, but this is a property which land possesses all the world over, where many people are congregated.

We may perhaps, take the phenomenal rise in the price of land as a good augury, deducting therefrom the following xi m :— The land isn exceed:ngly valuable, ergo the buildings erected will be highly artistic and of good material and substantial: and as a corollary we may assume that there may be at hard the shering in ,of another era of artistic work in Alexandria, and which permeating all life, shall bring pleasure alike to the designer and the worker, to the user as well as to the beholder.
Improvement of Alexandria,

Like other great towns, Berlin, Paris, and London, Alexandria is improving herself and borders. London has just opened a great new street, cot through a congeries of small streets at a cost of many millions sterling. Paris is busy with its underground railway. and in Germany a most excellent municipal law has been passed whereby municipalities are able to schedule surrounding lands for the future extension of their cities.

Alexandria has its fine tr ct of land partly reclaimed from the sea, and to the engineers of the Municipality much credit is due for their fine arrangement of tea wall and double lines of roads. That the elements may not have the mastery over the materials and construction of the sea wall, is the prayer of all who have welfare of Alexandra at heart, but of course time can only tell as to the result. A watchful eye might be kept over the doings of the waves always bearing in mind that in a wall as well as in a garment, "a stitch in time saves nine."
Example to our Municipality.

Like London with its new street 100 fee wide, Alexandria has in its new esplanade, an opportunity which comes hot rarely in the why of Municipalities, and though the London Council may in the main be a worthy model for other Municipalities, it has, to my mind, committed a grave error in the matter rf the architecture of its new street. It has shackled the architects with a style, which it has designated "Palladian Freely Treated" end the result, thus far, is not altogether satisfactory. Bat there is in the regulations of the Council of London as to the architecture of the new street a stringent clause as to materials. These most be of good stone, marble, granite or sound brick and stone combined. No "stucco" or plastering is to be permitted and in this the Alexandria Municipality may well follow the London Council.

Two questions now arise as to the future architectural development of Alexandria, and, here, I know fall well that there are plenty of good men, both native and foreign, who would say to me:—"A fig for your architectural development, let us have more commercial and monetary development." To this, history supplies answers in plenty. To take an instance The decline of Venice began at a period of great commercial prosperity in the fifteenth century. Her nobler life and chaster architectural days had already passed and the force of her energy was now given up to money-making, giving proof if any were needed, that the better days of Venice, or of any city, were those of which it, could be said of the people— that all were for the State and none for self or party. But this is by the way. Let us come to the two questions which concern material and style.
Material for building.

First as to material. Alexandria has no stone save the soft Mex stone end the native brick, which is also sofa badly burnt The material near at hand, therefore, is only fit for internal walls, and external walls covered with plaster. But Egypt abounds in good sandstone, limestone and red and grey granite. At Tourah there are stones which, if carefully selected, would make excellent building stone, and in making the section the analyses made by Mr. A. Lucas, of the Geological Department, Cairo, will be, if consulted, of the greatest service. Then there is the hard, compact sand-stone of which many of the ancient temples were built and which prove its durability This stone may still be ad without stint in the old quarrie in Upper Egypt.

In various parts of the Sudan some good building stones, as that used with affect in building some of the Sudan railway stations, as at Ed Darner, may be found. Above Omdurman in Gebel Awili there is a stone which, if carefully treated, would make good building stone. Of several samples of this stone I have had analyses made by a London expert. There need be no hesitation as to its use in a dry climate, and with treatment of its surface it may be made to withstand the alternations of wet and dry weather.
Stone Preservatives.

Further, many of the softer stones and even the better quality of the Mex stone might be treated with stone preservative, much as in Britain we treat the softer Bath stone : and here with regard to stone preservatives, I might add that I am now awaiting the arrival. of samples of five different solutions for the continuation of experiments already began, with the view of hardening the best qn^litv of the soft material at hand and so as to free it from its dependence on stucco. Then as to bricks. There are several ways of making bricks. The sand at Ramleh might be turned into brick and the brick earth might be better selected, washed and more thoroughly burned. Lastly, the supply of granite at Assouan is practically unlimited.
Granite from Assouan.

Egypt abounds, therefore, in material of which the architect can avail himself in which to design (shades worthy of the rising prosperity of Alexandria. But while I write my heart misgives me, and the question occurs •— Is there public spirit and enterprise enough in Alexandria or-in Egypt to undertake the quarrying working and transporting of granite from Assonan to Alexandria, and of course to all towns by the way? The granite is there in great masses. The apparently vast quantity used for the great dam 2,000 metres long by 37 metres high, has left no appreciable difference in the vast store awaiting the tool of the worker.

Determination, coupled with the love of the strong and beautiful, is all that is required. The resources of engineering can overcome all difficulties. The quarries border the Nile. The question of transit has already been considered and is reducible to so many piastres per ton.

For a government undertaking one can think of no better one than the establishment of vast granite works at Assouan. Egyptian granite as well as Egyptian antiquities, new and old, might find its way into European markets, even as Swedish granite finds its way to England, Scotland, and even Egypt Here, then, is a new Egyptian trade and an unlimited source of revenue.
Wanted-a bold renaissance.

But as I said, my heart misgives me, and judging from an incident which I witnessed the other day I am dubious as to the robustness of Alexandrian enterprise. Here is an account of the incident A piece of an ancient granite shaft about three metres long and 76 c/m. in diameter was discovered in a foundation, and rather than lift the valuable piece of material out of the trench it was left to lie where it was found and the foundation of the wall across which it lay was arched over it The piece of granite might have been used with effect in, say, a new facade in Cherif Pasha-street. But there it lies buried, the softer material is easier worked and handled. And as we think of the incident the imperative question comes up: If a valuable piece of granite cannot be raised a height of three metres, how can granite be transported for 700 miles? But it could have been done, of course, and done easily.

It is in these things we want a renaissance a re-birth of the old love of good work and the fearless handling of material. If I were to say. there is gold in the granite of Assouan, a Klondyke would result. Bat beneath the hard ragged exterior of the Assouan granite there is more than gold—there is beauty and lasting utility. It is matter for the Egyptian Government; for it, there is gold in the granite. The gold is in the pleasant and useful work it will supply to a large part of the ever-increasing population of Egypt.

THE LIGHTING OF CAIRO.
The following is extracted from the P.W;D. Report for 1904:—

Gas. 811 new lamps have been added at a cost, of some LE 2.400. This brings the total up to 3.813. This figure is hardly half of that required for the effective lighting of the city, and up to the end of 1904, the high rate changed for gas by the company necessited the suspension of any further extension. In the early days of 1905, however, responsible delegates of the company visited Egypt, and treated direct with the Government. The result has been satisfactory for both parties. The rate for gas has been reduced, an extension of the area has been granted to the company and many of the obscure points in the original concession have been recast and made clear. 3,252 lamps were fitted with incandescent burners in 1904—the results have been good.

Electricity.—81,3l8lamps(repreeentiagl,R43 private consumers) were connected in 1204, also 141 arc lamps. 1,765 metres of high-ten-sion and 6,639 metres of low-tension cable were laid in 1204. The number of lamps is rapidly increasing. The demand for the current has increased far more rapidly than was expected, and although the generating station was enlarged last year, it has already worked to its full capacity, and the company will be obliged to. erect a new; generating set next year. It has been found, impossible; to obtain any reduction in the price of electricity for private individuals, when altering the convention, at the commencement of this year. The present rate is very high, but the company protests that it is at present unable to reduce it. The existing rate, however, has only been fixed for a period of five years, and it is hoped that, by that time, it may be found possible to reduce the charges made to the public.

div.head: CHRONIQUE JUDICIAIRE
div.p: TRIBUNAL DE COMMERCE MIXTE D'ALEXANDRIE
Annulation de Saisie-Arrêt

Annal Varisco et Joseph Fermentons , avaient fait saisie-arrêt entre les maies de Principe, en sa qualité d'agent de la Cied As-suran ces "La Estella de Madrid.'' de tonte soin meqni serait dûe par lai à G. F-rruuia jusqu'à concurrrence d'oue somme de P. T. 23 368. intérêts compris. Par leur exploit introduit et'f d ir s-tance ils demandaient, en outre, au tribunal de valiler cette saisie-arrêt et de la convertir en saisie-exécution.

Les requérants se disaient,en effect, créanciers .1' de la somme de £ 145, montant de l'avance versée aux intimés sur la location du vapeur "Zarifa" et du chaland "Assouan" à eux loués et ayant fait naufrage avant de leur ê'relivrés; • 2 de P.T 6.231, valeur du charbon embarqué sur le chaland et perdu par la négligence des intimé.

Mais comme le remorqueur 'Zarifa" devant aller d Alexandrie dans la Mer Ronge devait lui aussi être approvisionné et que ces provisions consistaient précisément dans les 32 tonnes qui avaient été emha'quéea dans ses soutes, le tribunal a estimé q i'il y avait lieu de les faire entrer en ligne de compte et de condamner les demandeurs à payer aux intimés P. T. 1448 pour solde de tout compte.

div.head: L'ENREGISTREMENT DES BREVETS AU SOUDAN.
div.p: On demande souvent qu'elles sont les formalités à remplir pour revendiquer la proprié é exclusive d'ane invention ou d'ane marque de fabrique au Soudan Egyptien, afin de se réserver tous droits quant à leur usage.
Voici les renseignements que nous avons pn obtenir à ce sujet:

Eu l'absence d'an bureau de Brevets au Soudan, on doit, pour enregistrer un brevet ou une marque de fabrique quelconque dans ce pay°, déposer à office d i Legal Secretary d a Gouvernement Egyptien 4 Khartoum' are copie d'an certificat transcrit dans le Registre des Brevets et Marques de fabriques d'au tribunal Mixte de Commerce en Egypte et une note détaillée spécifiant la nature de invention.

div.head: GOMME ARABIQUE.
div.p: Les arrivages de la nouvelle récolte ont commencé et s'élèvent pour le moment de 50 à 100 kantars par j ur, mais par suite des fêtes da Baïram iis ont dû s'arrê er un peu, néanmoins on compte qu'ils vont reprendre régulièrement, et suivant lear importance on établira les cours.
Les prix actuels pour marchandise de la vieille récolte, dont il existe encore an stock insignifiant an Caire, sont de P.T. 85 à 87.

Les vendeurs sont très réservés eu ce qui concerne des ventes à livrer sur la nouvelle campagne, et n'oçent pas s'engager même à de bons prix, croyant 4 une hausse prochaine, vu l'épuisement du stock et l'incertitude sur l'importance de la nouvelle récolte.

Le Caire, 15 décembre.

Les télégrammes de Londres signalent une nouvelle hausse du taux d'escompte, porté de 3 '/2 à 4 0/0. C'et une élévation de 5/8 e-deux j eurs. On s'était décidément trop hâ é d'àbaîscer le loyer de l'argent à un nivean que justifiait sans douta une aisance renaissante, mais que ne conseillait peut-être pas la situation générale.
Le Consolidé anglais a perdu encore 1/8 à 83 1 /8 ; mais les valeurs égyptiennes ont conservé leurs prix de la veille.
A Paris, le Crédit Foncier a regagné 2 francs à 772.
loi, ee matin, le marché a été assez enimf. L'Agricole est plus soutenue à 9 3/16 achr-teurs. La National Bank est délaissée, ainsi que l'nction Crédit Foncier.
Les Enterprise and Development, dont nons parlons plus loin, sont très demandées. Laotien avance à 12 et la part de fondateur à 8 1/2.
Les Ciments, très mouvementés h eussent jrrqn'à 80, mus fléchissent vers la c ôtnre à 7 acheteurs ; les dividendes ont ouvert à 18 et clôturé à 20.
Bonne demande sur les Improprement Corporation, qui s'inscrivent à 4 1/8 aoheeurs.

Dans le groupe des Hôtels, on est pins faib'e sur les Nungovich, qu'ou offre à 10 13/16. Par contre, les National Hotels sont très demandés : ils ouvrent a 3 15/ 6 pour o'ô urer à 4 1/16 acheteurs. Les Baeh er sont fort soutenus à 2 15/ 6 acheteurs.
Faimi les petites valeurs, les E tates, en bonne rendanoe, avancent à £ l 17/32 avec de gros é hanges. Les Western Corporation se sont traitées à £ l 1/32 aveo un bon oo cirant d'affaires.
Noos devons apporter une modification à la note que noos avons publiée her pour expliquer la baisse q ui se produit sur les actions de la Société des Ciments d'Egypte.

La maison Lambert & Ralli ne vient pas d'acheter tout le stock disponible de la Sooiété des Ciments. De fait, cette mission est engagée depuis le ler mai dernier à prendre 15,000 tonnes la 1ère année, 20,0001a Sème et 24,' 00 la 3ème année.

En ce qui concerne l'aff dre de la Cairo He-liopolis Metropolitan Electric Railway Corn pany, elle a été traitée par MM. Lambert & Ralli en plus de leur cou rat, à des oonditions avantageuses préa' ableuaent arrêtée avec la Société des Ciments II s'agit de 10,000 à 12,0 0 tonnes à livrer par année pendant 10 ans.
Nons apprenons, d'antre part, que la Sooiété des Ciments d'Egypte vient d'être déclarée adjudicataire pour la fourniture de tout le ciment nécessaire à la Munie.palité d'Alexandrie pour l'année 1906.

Hier, après midi, a en lien, an siège social au Caire, l'assemblée générale extraordinaire de l'Euterprise and Development company. L'augmentation da capital oocial était à l'ordre du jour. Il s'agissait de le porter de L. E 160,000 à LE 4 '0,000, parsnite du dével ppn ment considérable des affaires de la Soc é é. M Rolin précédait la réunion.

Des renseignements qu'il a donnés il résnl e que les bénéfices à ce pur (L'exercice n'est pas encore clos) s'é èveut à 30,000) livres, produits I par la liquidation de deux affaires. Le capital initial se trouve entièrement employé et le S'Oié é a entamé d'autres affaires qui absorbe ront immédiatement le nouveau capital de mandé.
La nouvelle émission a été entièrement garantie par un syndicat belge, qui prendra la-actions à L.E. 11, o'eat-a dire avec une prime d'une livre.
Les 24,000 L.E de bénéfice provenant de l'opération seront passées au fonds de réserve.
L'augmentation du capital a été votée à longanimité, et l'assemblée s'est séparée aprè^ avoir félicité le conseil d'administration pour les résultats remarquables de sa gestion à ce jour.
Les cours da cotoa arrivent en hausse d'Amerique. Le spot a gagné 20 points, le janvier 10 et le Mai 12.
Liverpool e t également en bonne tendance.
Les arrivages se sont é.'evés à 47,000 balles contre 45,000.

div.head: Vade Mecum for the Homeward Bound
Picture Post Cards
div.p: "The Egyptian Gazette" Series is the most artistic collection to be found in Egypt.

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera, and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list showing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:-
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 4 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers, of the P.&O. North German Lloyd, Orient and Messageriea Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, and Bibby Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said, can now be made without change in 4 1/2 hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.
The most expensive but quickest through Continental routes are by P.&O. Brindisi express from Port Said, and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis" to Brindisi. One of these leaves port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; hero there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Donino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange ; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea, no hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza :

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino.and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO, may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of lake Maggiore has a mild climate and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, "Entombment," by Ciseri, and 'Tho Flight into Egypt," by Bramantion.
LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne, to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse

A delightful exeption from Lucerne is that to ENGELBERG. Take boat to Stansstad and from Stansstad it is about 1 hour and 40 min. by Electric Railway, with delightful scenery en route. The ascent of Titlis, is made from here, and the panoramic view of the Alps is grand; extending from Monte Rosa to the Black Forest, and from the Santis to the Matterhorn.

THE BERNESE OBERHAND.-INTERLAKEN a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbath and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D'OEX. 3,500 ft above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.

div.head: Egyptian Delta Light Railways Co., Limited.
div.p: Connections made with the most important trains of the State Railway in the Provinces of Behera, Gharbieh, Dakahlieh Charkieh and Galioubieh.Through service for goods between all stations of the Company andover 100 principal stations of the State Railway in Upper and Lower Egypt. Goods may also be through-booked from or to any station on Helouan Railway. The Company has 70 stations opened for public Telegraph Service in conjunction with all offices of the Government Telegraph Department.For time tables, tariffs and information apply to the offices at Cairo, Alexandria Damanhour, Tantah or Zagazig. 21416 31-12.905
